chat_history: Cruz: Baker.  You got it solved?
Narrator: And now we see her.  From the rear.  Slouched at her station.Looks like a skinny teenager in tousled tawny hair, rumpledoversized workshirt, vintage jeans.
Cruz: Actually. Yeh.
Narrator: Not a kid's voice. Throaty.  Music and whiskey and sex and effortless confidence.  Even the voice turns us on.
Cruz: Glances at his watch. What took you so long, Gin?  I called 4:30 this morn...
Narrator: And stops. Because she turns with a look that would freeze anyone to stone.
Gin: I was with someone, all right?

Narrator: Now we really see her. Delicate bones and features, slender body,radiating the power of a natural heart-stopping beauty.  Gin Gerbarker is 32, ethereal and feral at once.  Electric green eyes crackle with an intellect and a will that are not to be fucked with.
Cruz: So?  This is work.
Narrator: He is not kidding.  Stainless steel beneath the dapper.  They are a matched team.
Gin: Hector, I hardly know the guy. Why be impolite to strangers?
Narrator: And he smiles.  Maybe she's lying.  He likes her.
Cruz: Look at those assholes...
Narrator: He means the cops on live feed.
Cruz: If the Vermeer were lying on that table, they'd toss their doughnuts on it.
Gin: Yeh, well, they didn't insure it, so they don't have to solve this. To them it's a crime.  To us it's 24 mil, less re-insurance, which is...
Cruz: (grim) Only thirty percent, Gin.
Gin: Ouch.  Really?
Cruz: Which is why you're on this. Soft and straight.  You're the best.  I need you.
Gin: He came in through the window.
Cruz: That's not possib...
Gin: What's not possible is entry through the doors or the vents.  That would have triggered instant alarm.
Cruz: The windows are wired, too.
Gin: Only for trauma.  They used smart glass, where the sensors respond to violation of the panel's integrity.
Narrator: He's listening.  He always does with her.
Gin: I think he scaled the wall, popped the frame.  In one piece.
Narrator: She sounds awfully positive.  Then again, she always does.
Gin: Then, he only had to deal with heat and motion sensors.  They were on 60-second delay, so the owner wouldn't trigger the alarm just be walking arou...
Cruz: The pane weighs 200 pounds, the building's 1100 feet high.
Gin: This particular guy is the best. The best there ever was.
Narrator: Almost as if she knows who.  Cruz shakes his head...
Cruz: Popping the frame would trigger the alarm.
Narrator: She smiles.  First time.  Even at one-tenth power, it is dazzling light.  She touches the panel before her...
Cruz: I wrote a program and ran it, Dumbo.

Narrator: The live feed is replaced by a red-outlined rotating three-dimensional DIAGRAM of the living room.  The alarm box glows green.One window pane glows lavender.  She touches the panel, and the window shatters, the alarm instantly emits a PIERCING SCREECH.Reset.  As he watches.  This time the window SLIDES AWAY int othin air.  No sound.  A stick figure appears, crawls through the opening, and the alarm begins the slow beep we heard last night. Cruz just stares.
Gin: Here's how I figured it out...
Narrator: Live feed replaces the diagram.  Our camera ZOOMS toward a VASE oflilies by the window.  All the flowers are tilted in one direction.Over the lip of the vase, away from the window.
Gin: No one arranges flowers like that. It was the draft from the window.
Narrator: He turns to her.
Cruz: You said.  This particular guy.
Narrator: Now she is beaming.  Excited.  And just above a whisper...
Gin: Andrew MacDougal.
Narrator: Delighted at his stupefied reaction.
Cruz: Why not Houdini?  Or Pretty Boy Floyd?  Maybe Jesus Christ.
Gin: Because they couldn't do it.
Narrator: His slow smile.  This fucking kid.
Cruz: He's been out of the business. For ten years.
Gin: Maybe not.  No one ever proved, hell, even arrested him, for stealing anything.  But we all know he was numero ichiban for thirty years.  Why not forty?
Narrator: She's serious.
Cruz: Why?  Because of the Bozo switch? Guys have been copying his pack- rat signature for decades.  Maybe the thief wanted it to look like MacDougal.
Narrator: She doesn't even answer.  Just touches her panel, and one of thedata screens BLOWS UP to huge size.  It is...
Gin: A list of his private collection. Complete to three acquisitions last Thursday.

Narrator: Names scrolling up endlessly, next to titles, descriptions,estimated retail and black market values.  Turner, Corot, ThomasColes, DeKooning, Klimt, Cezannes, Odilon Redon, Braques, MaryCassatt...
Cruz: No Vermeer.  Nothing close.
Gin: Don't be a putz.  This is his legitimate collection, which he buys.  Presentable for any search warrant surprise party.
Narrator: Names keep rolling, Degas, Paul Klee.  Amazing.
Gin: What he rips off, he fences.  And the money feeds his portfolio of investments, which are daring, savvy, and obscenely succesf...
Cruz: Oh, I get it.  He has no interest in Vermeers, so that proves he stole one.  By that logic, he oughta be a suspect most of the time.
Narrator: She shakes her head, sadly.
Gin: You love to embarrass yourself.
Narrator: Touches her panel.  The big screen now shows a grainy videotape of...
Gin: The auction.  Where our client bought the painting...
Narrator: We see the Great Room of an English Country estate.  Perhaps a hundred attend.  Genteel to the max.
Gin: Ashcroft Hall, Buckingham shire, four weeks ago.
Narrator: The tape PANS five PAINTINGS on the block.  We recognize our Vermeer, the city of Delft, the canal, the bridge.  The view pulls back to include the crowd, and...
Narrator: freezes. One tiny section is circled.  And blows up twenty feet.high, so blurry as to be unrecognizable. Then, snaps to amazing resolution.  The image of...
Gin: Anyone we know?

Narrator: ...Andrew MacDougal, perhaps 60, as charismatic and shamelessly virile a face as one can recall. Etched with character and worldly experience, lit by a twinkle behind the razor-keen gaze.  Tall,wide shoulders, massive hands.  This guy would be more fun to fuck than fight.  By a lot.
Cruz: So he was there.
Gin: Staking it out.  Why bid, when you can mark the buyer, and jack it within the month?
Narrator: She leans way back in the molded chair. Lifts her long legs up onto the console.  They end in slender bare feet.  The toeswriggle.

Gin: At this moment, he is winging on JAL flight 307 to Narita, ostensibly to attend a prestigious auction at the Hotel Akura, which will include a mixed media collage/oil by Georges Braques, on which he supposedly has his eye.
Cruz: But you know better.
Gin: Bet your ass.  At Vegas odds.
Narrator: Touches the panel.  The big screen now holds three faces, three names.
Gin: Research reveals three known fences, still at large, who are believed to have brokered Vermeers to black market buyers.  Sandrine Palmer is hospitalized in Malta with ovarian cancer.
Narrator: One face and name disappears.  Two remain. Koichi and Naruhito .
